title: Malformed HTTP/2 SETTINGS frame leads to reachable assert
vulnerability_information:
I do not expect any form of cash bounty for this issue. If we have discovered a unique vulnerability I only ask that Jordan Zebor and Adam Cabrey of F5 Networks be crediting with finding the issue.

**Summary:** A reachable assert in the NodeJS HTTP/2 implementation can result in a denial of service. 

**Description:** Attackers can send a series of malformed HTTP/2 SETTINGS frames to reach an assertion in code, causing the node process to exit with SIGABRT. This has been observed in v13.8.0 and v14.0.0-nightly20200213e23b12e130.

## Steps To Reproduce:
1) Create an example HTTP/2 server. I used the example code from here https://nodejs.org/api/http2.html#http2_http2_createsecureserver_options_onrequesthandler

2) Create an example client to send the attached cases in a loop. In this case, I used an internal fuzz testing tool that I unfortunately cannot share but I can attach the test cases which I sent. We discovered that by sending a malformed SETTINGS frame over and over (roughly 25 in a row) the node process will SIGABRT. 

3) Observe node process crash after series of requests are sent. I can consistently trigger this issue in 13.8.0 and 14.0.0. I will provide a stack trace, stack trace when run under valgrind, and the test case I used to reproduce the issue. If the core file is needed I can provide that as well.

I believe this is where the assertion is triggered.
https://github.com/nodejs/node/blob/f3682102dca1d24959e93de918fbb583f19ee688/src/node_http2.cc#L1521

## Impact: A reachable assert which leads to SIGBART of the entire node process. It's a denial of service issue.

## Supporting Material/References:
Notice with the attached examples are prefixed with the order in which they were sent. If you already know how to do all the connection preface setup then simply send the settings anomaly frame on a new connection over and over again. A visual representation of the settings frame which causes the issue can be seen in "SETTINGS_FRAME_DETAILS.png".

## Impact

A reachable assert which leads to SIGBART of the entire node process. It's a denial of service issue that an unauthenticated attacker can easily achieve. The CVSS calculator on this portal seems to be classifying the issue as "Critical", which I don't agree with. I believe this to be a "High" severity issue with this CVSS score - https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H

activities.message:
Hi @jzebor,

Thank you for your submission. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Kind regards,
@turtle_shell

Thanks,

activities.message:
The HTTP/2 frames are all here in the case. I don't have a code snippet to share at this time but I suppose I can work on one if you need it. Basically sending the binary representation of what I've posted on an open socket is what I will work on for you.

What exactly are you expecting from me with regards to "check the memory dump" ? Do you want me to send you a core file with how to use gdb ? Please advise.

activities.message:
Hello @jzebor and thanks for your reply,

> Create an example client to send the attached cases in a loop. In this case, I used an internal fuzz testing tool that I unfortunately cannot share but I can attach the test cases which I sent. We discovered that by sending a malformed SETTINGS frame over and over (roughly 25 in a row) the node process will SIGABRT.

Can you provide an alternative way of testing it or at least send us the payload/code snippet that will crash the server? Otherwise, it is impossible to assess the problem if we cannot reproduce it.
Regarding the memory dump, are you using a special tool to retrieve it or it is inside some log file or it is printed out in STDERR/STDOUT?

Best regards,
@turtle_shell

We discovered that by sending a malformed SETTINGS frame over and over (roughly 25 in a row) the node process will SIGABRT.

Can you provide an alternative way of testing it or at least send us the payload/code snippet that will crash the server? Otherwise, it is impossible to assess the problem if we cannot reproduce it.

activities.message:
As stated in the original report, the payloads are attached in order 1_, 2_, 3_, 4_. If you can send those on a socket to the node HTTP/2 server in a loop it will crash. I understand about the reproduction issue and will work to help make it easier if you cannot use the payloads I've attached. 

For the memory dump I've posted to the case, I used both gdb and valgrind to review the stack trace which was included in the core dump (my system will produce a coredump when SIGABRT signal is sent to process). The backtrace does get printed to standard out upon crash but doesn't show the whole stack trace. I was only able to view the entire stacktrace in gdb. The command is "gdb /usr/bin/node /path/to/corefile". 

What specifically do you want to observe with the memory of process ? FWIW, I don't believe there is memory corruption as this case is a reachable assert. I did not observe any form of segmentation fault (SIGSEGV). Do you want me to check the corefile for something specific ? Do you want me to upload the corefile in question for your review ?
activities.markdown_message:
As stated in the original report, the payloads are attached in order 1_, 2_, 3_, 4_. If you can send those on a socket to the node HTTP/2 server in a loop it will crash. I understand about the reproduction issue and will work to help make it easier if you cannot use the payloads I've attached.

For the memory dump I've posted to the case, I used both gdb and valgrind to review the stack trace which was included in the core dump (my system will produce a coredump when SIGABRT signal is sent to process). The backtrace does get printed to standard out upon crash but doesn't show the whole stack trace. I was only able to view the entire stacktrace in gdb. The command is "gdb /usr/bin/node /path/to/corefile".

What specifically do you want to observe with the memory of process ? FWIW, I don't believe there is memory corruption as this case is a reachable assert. I did not observe any form of segmentation fault (SIGSEGV). Do you want me to check the corefile for something specific ? Do you want me to upload the corefile in question for your review ?

activities.message: Asserts should not be triggerable via network traffic. Thanks for the report, we'll look into this.
activities.markdown_message: Asserts should not be triggerable via network traffic. Thanks for the report, we'll look into this.

activities.message: @jzebor To confirm, doing something like `while true; do cat _1* _2* _3* _4*; done | nc localhost:3000` should be sufficient assuming a node server is doing an HTTP/2 listen on 3000? No connection setup required other than a TCP connect?
activities.markdown_message: @jzebor To confirm, doing something like while true; do cat _1* _2* _3* _4*; done | nc localhost:3000 should be sufficient assuming a node server is doing an HTTP/2 listen on 3000? No connection setup required other than a TCP connect?

activities.message: I have not tried without TLS. I can attempt with an h2c connection and let you know. Notice the stack trace does include calls to TLS* functions.
activities.markdown_message: I have not tried without TLS. I can attempt with an h2c connection and let you know. Notice the stack trace does include calls to TLS* functions.

activities.message:
In my testing, TLS enabled H2 server appears to be a requirement. I was unable to reproduce the crash with a cleartext H2 server.

Here is the reproduction test case that worked multiple times on my system. Noticed that the crash occured about 500 requests in. I did have one case that required to run two different runs with 500 requests each.

```
for x in {1..10000}; do echo $x; cat 1_connection_preface_frame 2_headers_frame 3_server_settings_ack_frame 4_settings_anomaly | openssl s_client -alpn h2 -connect localhost:8443; done
```
activities.markdown_message:
In my testing, TLS enabled H2 server appears to be a requirement. I was unable to reproduce the crash with a cleartext H2 server.

Here is the reproduction test case that worked multiple times on my system. Noticed that the crash occured about 500 requests in. I did have one case that required to run two different runs with 500 requests each.

for x in {1..10000}; do echo $x; cat 1_connection_preface_frame 2_headers_frame 3_server_settings_ack_frame 4_settings_anomaly | openssl s_client -alpn h2 -connect localhost:8443; done

activities.message: Thank you, that should help reproduce.
activities.markdown_message: Thank you, that should help reproduce.

activities.message: It turns out to be significantly easier to trigger if you just run two instances of the loop above at the same time.

Hello, any update on this issue ? I have not seen any indications that actions to fix this issue have been taken.

Thanks.

activities.message:
Sorry, we don't have the technical mechanisms to give access to the fix to just one person. I wish we could, so that you could see the proposed fixes and coordination required.

I can confirm a fix will be released as part of https://nodejs.org/en/blog/vulnerability/june-2020-security-releases/

activities.message: Subscribe to https://groups.google.com/forum/#!forum/nodejs-sec to get the notification pushed. As you can see from the history, it is very low traffic.

activities.message: @jzebor My apologies, our release process is overly complex and manual, and I missed your request "I only ask that Jordan Zebor and Adam Cabrey of F5 Networks be crediting with finding the issue.". I will edit the public blog post to include this.

activities.message: https://github.com/nodejs/nodejs.org/pull/3206 in review to credit researchers.

activities.message:
Thanks for the information and for giving credit post release. Can you please help me understand these last remaining questions before closing the case out ?

1) I didn't observe the same issue as your characterized for CVE-2020-11080.  I though the issue was a reachable assert which caused the node process to actually stop instead of causing a CPU spike. I never saw "the activity completed", it would simply assert and cause the node process to stop. The way it's worded makes it seem like a transient issue which is not what I observed. Can you please clarify your teams position on this ?

2) Why is the classification on this issue LOW ? A minimal CVSS estimate is medium. The observed impact I saw would make it a high per CVSS score. Help me understand this please. https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the information and for giving credit post release. Can you please help me understand these last remaining questions before closing the case out ?

1) I didn't observe the same issue as your characterized for CVE-2020-11080. I though the issue was a reachable assert which caused the node process to actually stop instead of causing a CPU spike. I never saw "the activity completed", it would simply assert and cause the node process to stop. The way it's worded makes it seem like a transient issue which is not what I observed. Can you please clarify your teams position on this ?

2) Why is the classification on this issue LOW ? A minimal CVSS estimate is medium. The observed impact I saw would make it a high per CVSS score. Help me understand this please. https://www.first.org/cvss/calculator/3.0#CVSS:3.0/AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:N/I:N/A:H
